TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE and living in GPE , GPE .
He is represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE , GPE .

On DATE the applicant was arrested and charged with the burglary of a house in the GPE area on DATE . The arrest followed the discovery of fingerprints at the scene which were later found by ORG at ORG to match those of the applicant . The responsible fingerprint officer , Mr S. Harris , concluded that he had no doubt about the fact that the fingerprint evidence provided a correct positive identification of the applicant having regard to the number of concordant ridge characteristics between the applicant ’s fingerprints and those found at the scene .
The fingerprint evidence was the only evidence linking the applicant to the burglary . The applicant maintained that he was innocent of the offence .
On DATE the applicant was remanded in custody by ORG . He was eventually released on bail on DATE .

While on bail the applicant ’s solicitor commissioned an independent fingerprint expert , PERSON , to consider the evidence against the applicant and to prepare a report . The expert attended at different police offices to examine various aspects of the fingerprint file in relation to the fingerprint evidence . PERSON concluded that he was unable to agree with the findings of PERSON . On DATE PERSON arranged a meeting with PERSON PERSON and another fingerprint officer from ORG . At that meeting the fingerprint officers demonstrated how PERSON had reached a positive identification of the applicant by comparing the fingerprints . Being dissatisfied with the explanations PERSON sought confirmation of his findings from another independent expert . The latter agreed with PERSON view that the positive identification was incorrect .

The applicant ’s trial was listed for DATE despite the concerns being voiced by the applicant ’s lawyer about the shortcomings in the fingerprint evidence . The trial was in fact adjourned when the applicant failed to attend court . On DATE the prosecution notified the applicant ’s lawyer that it would be offering no evidence . On DATE before ORG the prosecution formally offered no evidence , explaining that the police fingerprint officer had made an error of judgment when comparing the fingerprints . The charges against the applicant were dropped .

In a further expert report commissioned by the applicant ’s lawyer in a letter dated CARDINAL DATE and submitted on DATE , PERSON stated that this was the only case known to him where an attempt has been made to produce an erroneous identification to a court as evidence of identification . In his view , it should have been apparent to an experienced fingerprint officer that there could have been no genuine identification of the applicant on the strength of the fingerprint evidence . He concluded that there had been a serious flaw in the checking procedure . Had the procedure been rigourously adhered to , a false identification would have been excluded at an early stage . In his view , there was compelling evidence of gross negligence and incompetence on the part of members of ORG . However , from the information available to him he was unable to find anything to suggest that the mistake had been made with any malicious intent towards the applicant .

On DATE counsel advised the applicant ’s solicitor that an action for false imprisonment would be unlikely to succeed and that the facts did not give rise to a cause of action in negligence under domestic law , either with respect to the police or the fingerprint officer .
The applicant has applied to the Secretary of ORG for ex gratia payment of compensation for the time spent in custody . There is no information as to whether his request was successful .
